texts.definition: Specific diegetic social networks where membership is defined by what actions are favored, disfavored, and required.
markups: <style="Definition">Specific diegetic social networks where membership is defined by what actions are favored, disfavored, and required.</style>

A <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Faction">Faction</link></style> is a group that has members, criterion on membership, and accepted and disallowed behaviors. Different kinds of groups, such as a family, a gang, an army, are all examples of <style="CurrentLink">Factions</style>.

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/The%20Elder%20Scrolls%20III:%20Morrowind">The Elder Scrolls III: Morrowind</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/The%20Elder%20Scrolls%20IV:%20Oblivion">The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion</link></style> in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/The%20Elder%20Scrolls%20series">The Elder Scrolls series</link></style> provide many different types of <style="CurrentLink">Factions</style> for players to join. Each requires certain tasks and requirements to be fulfill for membership, and having this provides access to various tools and the possibility of advancement through completing additional goals.

Players' characters in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/World%20of%20Warcraft">World of Warcraft</link></style> can have different relations to the many <style="CurrentLink">Factions</style> that exists in games. Their standings are measure by the reputation value they have to each specific <style="CurrentLink">Faction</style>, and this can be affected through completing quests and killing monsters. Some rivaling factions are react diametrically different to some actions, so for example killing a pirate of the Bloodsail Buccaneers may result in a lower reputation among them while increasing ones reputation among the goblins of the Steamwheedle Cartel. However, players cannot join <style="CurrentLink">Factions</style> - this is instead handled through guilds which consist solely of players.

Membership in <style="CurrentLink">Factions</style> can be considered from three perspectives: what is required to join, what is required to continue being a member, and what is required to advance within their organizations.

Typically a few of the members in <style="CurrentLink">Factions</style> act as the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Social%20Gatekeepers">Social Gatekeepers</link></style> which determine who can join. The requirements that need to be fulfilled to satisfy these <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Social%20Gatekeepers">Social Gatekeepers</link></style> can range from having the right set of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Attributes">Attributes</link></style>, possessing the right set of <style="Link"><link="tools">Tools</link></style>, completing <style="Link"><link="quests">Quests</link></style>, or a combination of these. Joining <style="CurrentLink">Factions</style> may be <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Enforced%20Goals">Enforced Goals</link></style> due to <style="Link"><link="predetermined-story-structures">Predetermined Story Structures</link></style> but can also be <style="Link"><link="optional-goals">Optional Goals</link></style> which in the latter case <style="Link"><link="player-planned-development">Player-Planned Development</link></style>. If there are several <style="CurrentLink">Factions</style> which can be joined, an additional design choice is if one can only be member of one of these (creating a <style="Link"><link="selectable-set-goals">Selectable Set of Goals</link></style>) or if multiple memberships are possible.

Being, or not being, a player or human (which does not need to be the same thing due to the possibility of <style="Link"><link="ai-players">AI Players</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/NPCs">NPCs</link></style>) is another possible requirement for be allowed to join <style="CurrentLink">Factions</style>. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/World%20of%20Warcraft">World of Warcraft</link></style> is an example of a game using this differentiation, called the organization consisting only of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/NPCs">NPCs</link></style> for <style="CurrentLink">Factions</style> while those consisting only of players for <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Guilds">Guilds</link></style>. In contrast, the <style="Link"><link="single-player-games">Single-Player Game</link></style> <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Oblivion">Oblivion</link></style> in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Elder%20Scrolls%20series">Elder Scrolls series</link></style> has <style="CurrentLink">Factions</style> consisting of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/NPCs">NPCs</link></style> which can be joined by the player. It can be easy to ensure that the rules of <style="CurrentLink">Factions</style> are maintained, i.e. that in relation to these rules <style="Link"><link="actions-have-diegetically-social-consequences">Actions Have Diegetically Social Consequences</link></style>,  if there is at least one <style="Link"><link="algorithmic-agents">Algorithmic Agent</link></style> in the <style="CurrentLink">Factions</style> while <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Guilds">Guilds</link></style>, which only contain human players, run under <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Self-Facilitated%20Rules">Self-Facilitated Rules</link></style>. Of course, <style="CurrentLink">Factions</style> can play important roles in games without players being members of them. The most obvious case is as <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemies</link></style> to provide <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Conflicts">Conflicts</link></style> with many opponents but can also be used for <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/NPCs">NPCs</link></style> to control accessibility of <style="Link"><link="quests">Quests</link></style> and modifications of prices during <style="Link"><link="trading">Trading</link></style>.

Since membership is the result of completing a goal, it is typically that the membership is associated with some type of <style="Link"><link="rewards">Rewards</link></style>. The possibility to gain <style="Link"><link="new-abilities">New Abilities</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="improved-abilities">Improved Abilities</link></style> is common as this type of <style="Link"><link="rewards">Reward</link></style>, either in the form of training or through purchasable <style="Link"><link="tools">Tools</link></style>. Other possibilities include opportunity to recruit <style="Link"><link="companions">Companions</link></style> or that the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/NPCs">NPCs</link></style> owes players <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Favors">Favors</link></style>.

For each <style="CurrentLink">Faction</style> used in a game, there need to be a set of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Diegetic%20Social%20Norms">Diegetic Social Norms</link></style> define which regulate what is actions are acceptable to the members of that <style="CurrentLink">Faction</style>. For <style="CurrentLink">Factions</style> to have identities of their own, unacceptable behaviors by members typically need to have <style="Link"><link="penalties">Penalties</link></style>, i.e. <style="Link"><link="actions-have-diegetically-social-consequences">Actions Have Diegetically Social Consequences</link></style>; in some cases the consequence can be the <style="Link"><link="penalties">Penalty</link></style> of becoming a <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Outcasts">Outcast</link></style>. In addition, memberships in <style="CurrentLink">Factions</style> imply <style="Link"><link="loyalty">Loyalty</link></style>, either as a <style="Link"><link="predefined-goals">Predefined Goal</link></style> or as a <style="Link"><link="committed-goals">Committed Goal</link></style> (in the latter case, the memberships needs to have some benefits). While <style="Link"><link="loyalty">Loyalty</link></style> can be disregarded through inaction,  <style="Link"><link="internal-conflicts">Internal Conflicts</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="social-dilemmas">Social Dilemmas</link></style> can give players causes for <style="Link"><link="betrayal">Betrayal</link></style> and thereby provide an active option to break <style="Link"><link="loyalty">Loyalty</link></style>. This can lead to them not only becoming <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Outcasts">Outcasts</link></style> but also <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Traitors">Traitors</link></style>. Somewhat less destructive, <style="Link"><link="internal-rivalry">Internal Rivalry</link></style> can be used to provide more <style="Link"><link="challenging-gameplay">Challenging Gameplay</link></style>, and can be regulated by the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Diegetic%20Social%20Norms">Diegetic Social Norms</link></style>. The <style="Link"><link="internal-rivalry">Internal Rivalry</link></style> can either be achieved through static goals (often combined with the <style="Link"><link="predetermined-story-structures">Predetermined Story Structure</link></style>) but can also become a part of the game system through the use of <style="Link"><link="information-passing">Information Passing</link></style> as generic game events. While <style="CurrentLink">Faction</style> politics can be controlled by the game design in <style="Link"><link="single-player-games">Single-Player Games</link></style> this may be impossible to do completely in <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style>, so these may develop <style="Link"><link="internal-conflicts">Internal Conflicts</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="internal-rivalry">Internal Rivalry</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="social-dilemmas">Social Dilemmas</link></style> despite if they were part of the design intentions or not, especially for games with <style="Link"><link="persistent-game-worlds">Persistent Game Worlds</link></style>. One way to provide the norms of <style="CurrentLink">Factions</style> in broad strokes is to tie them to <style="Link"><link="character-alignments">Character Alignments</link></style>.

Advancements in <style="CurrentLink">Factions</style> require <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Hierarchical%20Fractions">Hierarchical Fractions</link></style> and typically require the completion of specific tasks, and can therefore easily take the form of <style="Link"><link="quests">Quests</link></style> which form a <style="Link"><link="goal-hierarchies">Goal Hierarchy</link></style>. While advancement may be <style="Link"><link="optional-goals">Optional Goals</link></style> and independent <style="Link"><link="predetermined-story-structures">Predetermined Story Structures</link></style>, they can also be integrated into the main <style="Link"><link="predetermined-story-structures">Predetermined Story Structure</link></style> of a game.

Depending on the level of diegesis in the game, <style="CurrentLink">Factions</style> can consist of players or their <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> (and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/NPCs">NPCs</link></style>). The diegesis typically also determines if <style="CurrentLink">Factions</style> are <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Hierarchical%20Fractions">Hierarchical Fractions</link></style> or not.

<style="CurrentLink">Factions</style> can function as important components in <style="Link"><link="predetermined-story-structures">Predetermined Story Structures</link></style>, and given the resource necessary to create <style="CurrentLink">Factions</style> they are usually part of <style="Link"><link="main-quests">Main Quests</link></style>. For hostile <style="CurrentLink">Factions</style> they allow <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Conflicts">Conflicts</link></style> that contain more than one person on each side, and thereby avoid the resolution of the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Conflicts">Conflicts</link></style> as soon as an <style="Link"><link="eliminate">Eliminate</link></style> goal of an <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemy</link></style> is achieved. For neutral or friendly <style="CurrentLink">Factions</style> the <style="Link"><link="character-development">Character Development</link></style> of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/NPCs">NPCs</link></style> can instead be an important part of the story told. The use of <style="Link"><link="internal-rivalry">Internal Rivalry</link></style> makes it possible to have <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemies</link></style> within players' own <style="CurrentLink">Factions</style> to force the use of other means than <style="Link"><link="combat">Combat</link></style> to complete <style="Link"><link="overcome">Overcome</link></style> goals.

For all types of <style="CurrentLink">Factions</style> the <style="Link"><link="quests">Quests</link></style> associated with them can easily form <style="Link"><link="goal-hierarchies">Goal Hierarchies</link></style> explained by the developing story line. These <style="Link"><link="quests">Quests</link></style> can also be the basis for giving them <style="Link"><link="open-destiny">Open Destinies</link></style> and the outcomes of these can be used to create variations in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Multiple%20Endings">Multiple Endings</link></style>.

Which <style="CurrentLink">Faction</style> an agent in a game belongs to is a <style="Link"><link="characteristics">Characteristics</link></style> of that agent. For <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style>, <style="CurrentLink">Factions</style> offers a natural reason for <style="Link"><link="teams">Teams</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Alliances">Alliances</link></style>. This in turn often leads to <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Social%20Interaction">Social Interaction</link></style> since the <style="CurrentLink">Factions</style> function as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Social%20Organizations">Social Organizations</link></style>. While <style="Link"><link="teams">Teams</link></style> may still occur with <style="Link"><link="algorithmic-agents">Algorithmic Agents</link></style> and thereby also in <style="Link"><link="single-player-games">Single-Player Games</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Social%20Interaction">Social Interaction</link></style> is less likely since it would require that a player considers an <style="Link"><link="algorithmic-agents">Algorithmic Agent</link></style> as a social individual. Many times making the joining of a <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Faction">Faction</link></style> is a <style="Link"><link="rewards">Reward</link></style> in that it can provide access to information, training, and trading of specific <style="Link"><link="tools">Tools</link></style>. By doing so, becoming a member of a <style="CurrentLink">Faction</style> can the requirement to complete a <style="Link"><link="gain-information">Gain Information</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="gain-competence">Gain Competence</link></style>, or <style="Link"><link="gain-ownership">Gain Ownership</link></style> goal, but more likely it will be a <style="Link"><link="supporting-goals">Supporting Goal</link></style> to one of these goals since it may be part of <style="Link"><link="goal-hierarchies">Goal Hierarchies</link></style> or require <style="Link"><link="trading">Trading</link></style>. When players have had the chance of choosing whether to join <style="CurrentLink">Factions</style> or not, the different goals provided in this fashion support <style="Link"><link="player-planned-development">Player-Planned Development</link></style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Factions</style> create simple social constructs that can be used to introduce social interaction to gameplay. While joining <style="CurrentLink">Factions</style> may require befriending with or making favors to <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Social%20Gatekeepers">Social Gatekeepers</link></style>,  keeping ones status may require the <style="Link"><link="continuous-goals">Continuous Goal</link></style> of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Diegetic%20Social%20Maintenance">Diegetic Social Maintenance</link></style> and advancement may support <style="Link"><link="higher-level-closures-gameplay-progresses">Higher-Level Closures as Gameplay Progresses</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="narration-structures">Narration Structures</link></style> through the use of <style="Link"><link="goal-hierarchies">Goal Hierarchies</link></style>. Given that <style="CurrentLink">Factions</style> typically have <style="Link"><link="penalties">Penalties</link></style> for breaking <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Diegetic%20Social%20Norms">Diegetic Social Norms</link></style>, and advancements within <style="CurrentLink">Factions</style> may provoke <style="Link"><link="internal-rivalry">Internal Rivalry</link></style>, the use of <style="CurrentLink">Factions</style> in games typically has the consequence of <style="Link"><link="actions-have-diegetically-social-consequences">Actions Have Diegetically Social Consequences</link></style>. These consequences imply that players have to choose between complying with an <style="Link"><link="enforced-agent-behavior">Enforced Agent Behavior</link></style>, that can include both a <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Limited%20Set%20of%20Actions">Limited Set of Actions</link></style> as well as requiring actions at certain times, or placing themselves in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Risk/Reward">Risk/Reward</link></style> situations through by doing actions that are not acceptable by <style="CurrentLink">Faction</style> rules. Both joining and being cast out of <style="CurrentLink">Factions</style> are examples of <style="Link"><link="persistent-game-world-changes">Persistent Game World Changes</link></style>.

Given that <style="CurrentLink">Factions</style> can make goals, <style="Link"><link="rewards">Rewards</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="penalties">Penalties</link></style> apply to all members, the pattern is often modified by <style="Link"><link="mutual-goals">Mutual Goals</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="shared-penalties">Shared Penalties</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="shared-rewards">Shared Rewards</link></style>. Since players may need to live with the effects, having <style="CurrentLink">Factions</style> in <style="Link"><link="persistent-game-worlds">Persistent Game Worlds</link></style> tend to strengthen the effects of all the consequences mentioned above.

<style="Link"><link="actions-have-diegetically-social-consequences">Actions Have Diegetically Social Consequences</link></style>,
